entry.title: üß¨Research x üí∞ Business : What change my perspective?

link.title: üß¨Research x üí∞ Business : What change my perspective?

entry.summary: Not long ago, someone asked me:‚ÄúWorking in a company might be repetitive ‚Äî not as daring or unpredictable as academic research. Would you still be interested?‚ÄùThen I came across the story of the Nobel laureates who discovered G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) ‚Äî Drs. Brian Kobilka and Robert Lefkowitz ‚Äî and my perspective completely shifted.üî¨ What Are GPCRs?GPCRs form one of the largest families of receptors in the human body and serve as major drug targets.In fact, around 40% of all drugs today act on GPCRs.Examples include Œ≤-adrenergic receptors, histamine receptors, muscarinic receptors, and dopamine D‚ÇÇ receptors ‚Äî names that anyone in pharmacology or public health will instantly recognize.These receptors are behind the actions of asthma medications, antihypertensives, antihistamines, psychiatric drugs, and many more.The discovery of GPCRs has led to an enormous variety of treatments across countless diseases.üéì The Surprise Behind the ScientistWhile listening to a Nobel lecture (I think it was Kobilka‚Äôs talk), I started to wonder:What kind of life does a professor like this have? Was he buried in the lab all his life until he made that discovery?Turns out ‚Äî absolutely not.To my amazement, Dr. Kobilka has seven children and has founded at least three companies,each one built directly on his GPCR research.That moment flipped everything I thought about research upside down.Research isn‚Äôt just research ‚Äî it can evolve into business, innovation, and real-world change.And then I realized ‚Äî‚ÄúWait‚Ä¶ if people like him don‚Äôt take these discoveries forward, then who possibly could?‚Äùüíº Beyond the LabEvery stage of research has meaning.Not every project should become a business, but when something truly has potential ‚Äî it deserves the chance to grow.This business perspective isn‚Äôt easy.It‚Äôs no less challenging than academia ‚Äî maybe even tougher.Academic research might be thrilling for its novelty,but corporate work turns those ‚Äúsacred‚Äù discoveries from the pedestal into tangible realities ‚Äîthings people can touch, use, and benefit from.And in doing so, it brings momentum back into science itself.üí° A Changed MindsetSince that day listening to Kobilka, my mindset has completely changed.I used to follow great scientists just through their publications,but now I get excited when I see they also hold patents.Recently, I even came across a Thai company that has patented 15 bioinformatic algorithms ‚Äî and honestly, that blew my mind.

entry.title: üíª I started coding just because my finger pained

link.title: üíª I started coding just because my finger pained

entry.summary: I had to analyze data from 96- or 384-well plates ‚Äî each exported as a CSV file with thousands of rows. Sounds familiar? Yes! 96 or 384 wells ‚Äî the well plates from the wet lab. My data came from 2D cell culture imaging, where I had to analyze single-cell information.I opened each file, searched for specific values, and repeated the same thing again and again.What I faced were:- Finger pain üòÇ- Human weakness ‚Üí human error after half a day of doing this- Forgetting to save ‚Üí all work gone- Changing cut-offs ‚Üí meant redoing everything from the start (and you know how often supervisors change them!)I realized all of this was just repetition. I knew every step ‚Äî I just had to do it again for every well (or many plates).So I told my supervisor I wanted to use coding/programming to automate it. His answer? No. He wanted me to do it manually ‚Äî ‚Äúby eyes‚Äù ‚Äî to get results faster.But I believed I could do more. So I decided to learn coding (R) secretly. I didn‚Äôt tell him ‚Äî I just kept maintaining all the usual lab work, while learning programming on my own.It wasn‚Äôt easy. It took months of effort, but I had a goal: to make my research more efficient and reproducible.After some fast and furious learning, I wrote my own code, fixed bugs, and validated that it worked the same as manual analysis. The result? No human error, finished in a minute, and I could change the cut-off anytime by typing a new number. Beautiful!I finally applied it to other experiments too. My supervisor was impressed ‚Äî finally! üòÜA hidden benefit of programming is that it does what you already do ‚Äî just faster and more accurately. If you‚Äôre curious how coding can help you, start by asking: üí° ‚ÄúWhich task repeats until my fingers hurt?‚ÄùIf you can answer that, you already have your first step into coding.üß¨ Here‚Äôs my project about this: Phenomics ‚Äì High-Throughput Imaging (https://lnkd.in/gX5nKNRp)=============Build a greater science together with me! Here is my blogsüå∏ Thai language: NO CANCER FB page/Blogger (https://lnkd.in/gQa3apBc)üß¨ English language: The Whispers of Biology (LinkedIn/Blogger) (https://lnkd.in/gRTnrpRz)#ScienceCommunication #Bioinformatics #ComputationalBiology #Rprogramming #LabAutomation #WomenInSTEM #NoCancerThailand #TheWhispersOfBiology

entry.title: üèÖ Nobel Prize 2025 ‚Äì T-Rex (Treg): The Peacekeeping Boss of the Immune Army

link.title: üèÖ Nobel Prize 2025 ‚Äì T-Rex (Treg): The Peacekeeping Boss of the Immune Army

entry.summary: Let‚Äôs break it down scene by scene so it‚Äôs easy to follow. Ready? Let‚Äôs roll! üé¨ üé¨ Scene 1: The War Inside the Body Inside our body lives a massive army of dinosaur soldiers‚Äîour immune system‚Äî guarding the city of ‚ÄúBodyville‚Äù from enemies like viruses, bacteria, and cancer cells. They‚Äôre always ready for battle‚Äî but here‚Äôs the catch‚Ä¶ sometimes, these dino-soldiers go berserk! üò± They start firing at everything in sight‚Äî even innocent citizens like the liver, eyes, or skin. And that‚Äôs how autoimmune diseases begin‚Äî when your body‚Äôs own army can‚Äôt tell friend from foe. ü¶ï Scene 2: Enter the Boss ‚Äì T-Rex the Peacemaker In 2025, the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine üèÖ was awarded to Mary Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell, and Shimon Sakaguchi for discovering the Regulatory T cell (Treg) ‚Äî the real-life T-Rex boss of the immune army! ü¶ñ Yes, this T-Rex doesn‚Äôt roar to fight ‚Äî it roars to calm the troops down. üß† Scene 3: The Birth of the T-Reg Unit Tregs are the peacekeepers of the immune army. Their job? Stop fellow soldiers from attacking innocent cells. When another immune cell is about to shoot, Treg shouts special chemical codes ‚Äî IL-10, TGF-Œ≤, and CTLA-4 ‚Äî which roughly translate to: ‚ÄúHEEEEY! Cease fire! That‚Äôs one of us!!‚Äù The moment the code is heard, the troops drop their weapons. ü´° üß¨ Scene 4: The Secret Code ‚Äì FOXP3 Every Treg carries a secret badge ‚Äî a gene called FOXP3. This is their ‚Äúborn-to-lead‚Äù mark ‚Äî a divine sword of peace üîÆ‚ú®. If the FOXP3 gene breaks, Tregs disappear, and the immune army turns against itself üí• ‚Äî causing diseases like IPEX syndrome, where the body‚Äôs defense system self-destructs. That‚Äôs how scientists realized: ‚ÄúWe survive every day because Tregs keep the peace within us.‚Äù üè∞ Scene 5: The Double-Edged Sword Too much or too little T-Rex power can both be dangerous. Too aggressive ‚Üí Autoimmune diseases ‚öîÔ∏è Too lazy ‚Üí Cancer or infections sneak through ü¶† So the Treg boss must keep perfect balance ‚Äî knowing when to fight and when to hold fire. ‚öñÔ∏è üèÖ Scene 6: Why This Deserves a Nobel This discovery changed how we see immunity forever. We used to think: ‚ÄúA strong immune system means always fighting.‚Äù But now we know: ‚ÄúA wise immune system knows when to stop.‚Äù That‚Äôs the essence of Peripheral Immune Tolerance ‚Äî the principle that keeps our defense system in check. As the Nobel Committee beautifully put it: ‚ÄúA fundamental discovery about the principle that keeps our immune system in check.‚Äù üåø The Take-Home Message ‚ÄúOur body stays healthy not because it fights hard ‚Äî but because it knows when to stop.‚Äù üíö So this year, the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2025 goes to the discovery of... ü¶ñ‚ú® Tregs ‚Äì The Peacekeeping Commanders of the Human Body! ‚ú®ü¶ñ #NobelPrize2025 üèÖ #NobelMedicine2025 #Treg #RegulatoryTCells #PeripheralImmuneTolerance #ImmuneSystem #ScienceExplained #MedicalDiscovery #ImmunologyFun #NobelPrizePark #‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏•‡πÇ‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏ö‡∏•2025 #‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏ö‡∏†‡∏π‡∏°‡∏¥‡∏Ñ‡∏∏‡πâ‡∏°‡∏Å‡∏±‡∏ô #‡∏ß‡∏¥‡∏ó‡∏¢‡πå‡πÄ‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡πÉ‡∏à‡∏á‡πà‡∏≤‡∏¢
